div.p:
In reply to your kind note,
Letter not found. dear Dr Bride, I beg to observe, that I do not send by any fixed arrangements my publications on behalf of the Government to particular English or foreign institutions regularly , because I have never enough copies to satisfy all demands and must therefore be guided by circumstances. My sending out of my works is mainly restricted to men of science, with whom I am in litterary correspondence, and who send for the continuation of my own researches their publications in return. […]
text obscured in p/c/
often enough breaks the communication […]
text obscured in p/c/
or new men of science come forward. I distribute therefore the copies according to the contents of any new works of mine, one publication being more important to one recipient, an other more to an other. As a rule however the Publications of my Department go to the Directors of the principal botanic Gardens, of which there [are]
editorial addition — word omitted in MS. many in Europe and some in India &c. The few Universities, which get my works are at Madrid, Coimbra and Tokio. I also send them to the Royal & Linnean
& Linnean interlined insertion. Society of London and the Colonial Institute and to several other scientific or literary Institutions in different parts of the world, but cannot send them to all those in toto of which I am a member honorary or other wise. In the eleventh vol. of the Fragmenta I have mentioned on the title page the Societies, to which I belong. To the British Museum and to the great libraries of Europe and America my volumes are not sent by me.

Probably these remarks may suffice for your purposes; but if not, then I will gladly afford further information I have to thank you for your kindness of affording me on several occasions latterly again aid in my studies by the loan for a day or so of works from your grand Institution.
